1080477891249430529 [2019-01-02] @visakanv 💜 62 🔁 3
a funny-sad thing is going through Quora questions that have marketing spam in the answers, clicking on the links and finding that the startups have since gone out of business

funny because they wasted their time

sad because they polluted our commons
↓
1261530103323885575 [2020-05-16] @visakanv 💜 24
I wanna elaborate on this, because I don't think many people appreciate just how costly polluted commons is. It's not obvious. Polluted commons make good people less likely to want to participate. It makes people trust each other less. It makes people put in less effort
↓
1261530815143358464 [2020-05-16] @visakanv 💜 17
people get so used to operating with the assumption that the public commons *must* necessarily be a cesspool of filth and bullshit that they might even struggle to imagine it any other way. and yet there are clearly variances across different sections of different public spaces
↓
1261531673918750721 [2020-05-16] @visakanv 💜 12
I would even maybe argue that you can think of several  golden ages as instances in which some subset of some public sphere in some city was uncommonly receptive to high-quality discourse – and those lead to tremendous cultural and scientific progress  https://t.co/f0f7HKFx8K
  [Quoting @visakanv: Interesting bit from Bertrand Russell about the Dutch golden age, resonates with @DavidDeutschoxf's riffs about conjecture and criticism https://t.co/vfizFuZXYq]
↓
1261531933193822208 [2020-05-16] @visakanv 💜 20 🔁 1
it takes a diverse group of smart, kind, thoughtful people to be able to find each other, play and experiment with each other, and yes challenge and criticize each other – respectfully enough – in order to produce the best work that the world has ever seen

this is not fiction!!!
↓
1261532536842317824 [2020-05-16] @visakanv 💜 28
"huh but what does that have to do with marketing spam on quora??"

hardly anybody I know worth talking to spends any time on quora any more. it was once a fascinating coffeehouse of thoughtful people having interesting conversations. it felt like it was really going somewhere
↓
1261533636932730883 [2020-05-16] @QiaochuYuan 💜 10
@visakanv i went through a cycle in grad school where i'd periodically quit quora because it was exhausting filtering through the terrible questions to find good ones i could give fun answers to. i never understood why they were so bad at filtering questions. eventually stayed gone

1195656478654267392 [2019-11-16] @visakanv 💜 154 🔁 14 💬 2
I notice that @Twitter is experimenting with how it presents threads, prioritizing showing other people's replies to a thread over the continuity of the thread itself, making it look like threads end sooner than they do

I knew the golden age of threading would end eventually https://t.co/7IwDM3XHOX
Images:
  - [Image #0] The image is a screenshot of a tweet thread by Visakan Veerasamy. The tweet thread is as follows:
    
    Visakan Veerasamy (@visakanv) 
    "I saw someone tweet 'I wish smart writing came to me as easily as dumb tweeting' and I am here to share with you my strategy for using the latter to precipitate the former
    4:05 PM · Jan 24, 2019 · Twitter for iPhone"
    
    Visakan Veerasamy (@visakanv) - Jan 24
    Replying to @visakanv
    "The first rule of smart writing is you must recognise what smart writing is. Sounds simple enough but most people fail at this. Lots of smart writers get their good quotes ignored and their tepid quotes celebrated. This lowers everybody's standards. Orwell warned about this"
    
    Visakan Veerasamy (@visakanv) - Jan 24
    "If you want to write well, I think you may need to spend more time identifying good writing than actually writing. At least at the start, but IMO, *always*. You need to develop your aesthetic taste re: what good *is*. No one else can do this for you"
    
    Visakan Veerasamy (@visakanv) - Dec 18, 2018
    "steve jobs said a bunch of really insightful things over the years, but it can be surprisingly tedious to find them because there's so much noise from people over-quoting the inspirational babble. I find myself thinking this a few times a year; probably worth making my own set"
    
    The tweet has 31 retweets and 136 likes.
↓
1195777305135603712 [2019-11-16] @visakanv 💜 78 🔁 4
@Twitter wow so I've had 7 hours to get used to this and I really fucking hate it. it's completely broken my experience of twitter. I make threads so that I can revisit them. now I have to click dozens of times to expand my own replies on my own threads. seriously fuck this

OSes & ways-of-being 😍👇

Part of what is messy about contemporary technology is the everythingness of everything. Hard to stay focused in reading a book while reading it on a device that's also everything else. https://t.co/xfrs2NTD4x
  [Quoting Tweet 1120919728157888512 (missing)]

1204671940633468928 [2019-12-11] @Malcolm_Ocean 💜 4
The first way Complice uses modal states is by separating the daily workflow of the today page into three phases:

https://t.co/8L5sPXB1Js
  [Quoting Tweet 1204658580860915712 (missing)]
↓
1204671941703086080 [2019-12-11] @Malcolm_Ocean 💜 4
By separating intention-setting & reflection out from do-tasks mode, Complice blocks certain user intents, & in the process creates clearer contexts for when to do these different things.

More is possible here—it's still easy to fall into old patterns.
https://t.co/uws5XQjYzh
  [Quoting @Malcolm_Ocean: @QiaochuYuan @andy_matuschak & while it has an "intention" list instead of a "task" list, they're still structurally/functionally very similar to tasks so it's easy to fall back into old patterns.  If you want to help develop next iteration of Complice, get in touch! My full-time focus is elsewhere atm.]
↓
1204671946543288320 [2019-12-11] @Malcolm_Ocean 💜 3
2nd modal type guides momentary flow of user's choice-making to be more conscious & intentional.

If you don't do something one day, instead of it staying on the list tomorrow, you have to consciously intend it again. And after a couple of days skipped, Complice starts prompting: https://t.co/s7lAvZPsC1
Images:
  - [Image #0] The image shows a screenshot of a task management interface. To recreate this image, start by creating a white text box with a gray border. At the top of the box, display the text "You sure? 4x skipped..." in black font. Below this, write the question "If this is important, how are you going to make it happen today?" in smaller gray text.
    
    In the middle of the box, show the task "1))))) write about Goal-Crafting Intensive Workshop" in purple font, with a large white text box underneath for input.
    
    At the bottom of the box, include two buttons: a gray "Cancel" button on the left and a purple "Keep" button on the right.
↓
1204671948028088320 [2019-12-11] @Malcolm_Ocean 💜 2
This adds friction—in a place where friction helps the user stay in touch with what they deeply care about 💖

Often there's a reason we don't do something today, and if we don't stop to listen, we might not notice something our intuition knows.

https://t.co/ujzxqvx36c
  [Quoting Tweet 1204660078915260417 (missing)]
↓
1204671949164752898 [2019-12-11] @Malcolm_Ocean 💜 2
So! There are some examples of modal interfaces used to nudge users towards valuable and easily-overlookable parts of workflows, and help them curate their focus.

I'm about to go abstract again, so open this link in a new tab & check out Complice later 🚀 https://t.co/OCzW6dsxkN
↓
1204671950276177921 [2019-12-11] @Malcolm_Ocean 💜 2
Okay, abstract again: what does nurturing design look like on the level of an operating system? There are some neat hacks that a few friends of mine have tried, to give their computer different modes, oriented to work or play or other options.

Easier on desktop than on phone.
↓
1204671951278608384 [2019-12-11] @Malcolm_Ocean 💜 3
What if you could boot up your phone into a mode where you couldn't access any of your messenger apps?

What if you could boot it up into a mode that only had your ebook reader & notes app?

What about a mode where messages can be sent but not received? (Hard to do on OS lvl)
↓
1204671952247574528 [2019-12-11] @Malcolm_Ocean 💜 1
How long would it have taken for them to invent airplane mode if it hadn't been required by airplanes???

Half-decent do-not-disturb & silence & notification control just hit android a couple years ago.

& that's tiny stuff.
↓
1204671957779853312 [2019-12-11] @Malcolm_Ocean 💜 1
Ways of being. What matters.

In Complice, almost everything one does is connected to a goal/purpose. Many people then want to have those goal names/colors elsewhere to organize things.

WorkFlowy, IFTTT+Hue, Gmail labels (out of date), post-its (can't find photo) https://t.co/KzurwAOEim

1204671959197454336 [2019-12-11] @Malcolm_Ocean 💜 2
What would it look like for "thing I care about" to be a sort of natural object that syncs between apps, in the way that contacts, calendars, docs do?

It's tough. No matter how meaningful, any articulation of purpose is at best oversimplified and at worst a proxy.
↓
1204671960141185024 [2019-12-11] @Malcolm_Ocean 💜 3 [(SEED) type=quote_of_root]
But still; currently companies are pouring billions of dollars into optimizing their apps to hack peoples' brains to make metrics go up. Design by proxy, not by vision, purpose, or a sense of alignment with the *user's* vision, purpose, or empowerment.
